A train enthusiast needed more than just one mode of transport to take the ride of a lifetime in Southland. 
Neal Purseglove travelled all the way from Yorkshire in the United Kingdom to ride the AB608 Passchendaele from Picton to Bluff. 
Purseglove and his fellow passengers were greeted by a large crowd, who braved the cold wind and bundled up in their winter woollies to see the 100-year-old steam locomotive whistle its way to the Invercargill train station on Thursday afternoon. 
"I've really enjoyed it and I like New Zealand greatly," Purseglove said. 
"We've been blessed with good weather, even though the forecast didn't say so." 
Steam Incorporated excursion organiser John Bovis said Passchendaele was carrying mostly Australian passengers, as well as Danish, English and Kiwi patrons. 
"[I'm] very proud and it's satisfying to see it maintained and restored for everyone else to enjoy," Bovis said. 
More than 50 people, young and old, were at the station to greet the historical locomotive. 
Jack Stirling, 88, said being on the platform brought back feelings of nostalgia from his school days and remembered "unofficially" helping the guards out "with shunting Ad Feedback 
"In my secondary school days I used to ride in and out on the Tokanui train," Stirling said. 
Passchendaele 's tour of the South Island began in Picton on Monday to celebrate not only the centenary of World War I, but also 100 years since the locomotive itself was built. 
Built in Christchurch in 1915, the locomotive was the chosen to haul members of the royal family around when they visited the South Island in the 1920s. 
It travelled more than 2.4 million kilometres before it was withdrawn from service in 1967. 
Invercargill Mayor Tim Shadbolt was there to greet Passchendaele as it rolled in. He was pleasantly surprised at the number of people who showed up. 
"I'm amazed at the size of the crowd. It may be an ancient form of technology but it shows the interest," he said. - Stuff
